repnme.cdata!:
Croatia - Second Science and Technology
            Project : environmental management framework

abstracts.cdata!:
The objectives of the Second Science and
            Technology Project are to: improve the capacity of
            Croatia's Research and Development (R&D) and
            innovation institutions to implement Europe 2020 strategy
            for increased investments in R&D through efficient
            absorption of European Union (EU) funds, and to develop a
            pipeline of public and private R&D projects, including
            research groups, that could qualify for financing through EU
            structural funds. Negative impacts most commonly include:
            dust and noise due to excavation, demolition and
            construction; management of demolition construction wastes
            and accidental spillage of machine oil, lubricants, etc.,
            encroachment to a private property, damage to historical or
            cultural property or unknown archaeological sites, traffic
            disturbance, surface or ground water, and soil pollution or
            erosion. Mitigation measures include: 1) the local
            construction and environment inspectorates and communities
            have been notified of upcoming activities; 2) during
            interior demolition use debris chutes above the first floor;
            3) there will be no open burning of construction/waste
            material at the site; 4) during operations the engine covers
            of generators, air compressors and other powered mechanical
            equipment should be closed, and equipment placed as far away
            from residential areas as possible; 5) the site will
            establish appropriate erosion and sediment control measures;
            6) waste collection and disposal pathways and sites will be
            identified for all major waste types expected from
            demolition and construction activities; 7) monitoring of new
            wastewater systems (before/after) will be carried out; and
            8) special facilities for segregated healthcare waste.

16702558.majtheme: Human development,Trade and integration,Financial and private sector development

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Science and Technology
            Project (STP) for Croatia were as follows: outcomes were
            satisfactory, the risk to development outcome was
            substantial, the Bank performance was moderately
            satisfactory, and the Borrower performance was also
            moderately satisfactory. Some lessons learned included: a
            first lesson learned from the STP is that innovation related
            projects may achieve tangible results within a relative
            short time. STP achievements indicate that Croatia's
            innovation performance was not constrained by a lack of
            ideas, as sometimes argued, but by the availability of
            appropriate institutions, such as Technology Transfer
            Organizations (TTOs), early-stage financing and mentoring
            services. A second lesson derives from factors seemingly
            critical for STP achievement focus on well defined,
            quantifiable targets (enabling commercialization of publicly
            funded research and supporting Small and Medium Size
            Enterprises, or SME investments in Research and Development,
            or R&D). A third lesson can be learned from what STP
            could not achieve, namely: restructuring research institutes
            and promoting a venture capital industry. The failure in
            fostering restructuring of research organizations was caused
            by a combination of political and technical difficulties.
            While a complex political economy is to some extent inherent
            to any restructuring process, a technical difficulty found
            in STP was related to definition of the own concept of
            restructuring, as BI did not count with direct government
            support and was financially self-sustained. Finally, a
            fourth lesson relates to sustainability of achieved results.
            By the end of the project, funds for continuation of the
            newly created programs had not been secured. The legal
            status of Business Innovation Centre of Croatia (BICRO) and
            Unity through Knowledge Fund (UKF) is currently being
            reviewed by the new administration. TTOs still have to fully
            integrate with their parent organizations (RBI and
            Universities of Zagreb and Rijeka) and are currently
            struggling to finance operating costs. Solutions, however,
            are envisaged.

repnme.cdata!: Croatia - Science and Technology Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Science and
            Technology Project for Croatia are: 1) to enable research
            and development (R&D) institutions to commercialize
            research outputs; and 2) to increase the ability of
            enterprises, particularly small and medium sized companies,
            to invest in R&D activities. The project has been
            restructured in August 2009, December 2010, and March 2011.
            Since then it successfully launched activities that enabled
            the commercialization of research results and research
            capacity and increased the ability of small and medium sized
            companies to invest in research and development activities.
            The project rating is satisfactory. The project will close
            on May 31, 2011, and proposed reallocation is necessary to
            optimize the use of funds until the project closing date.
            The percentage of financing under the loan expenditure
            categories remains the same.

display_title.display_title:
Croatia - Science and Technology
            Project : restructuring  (Vol. 2) : Data sheet

repnme.cdata!:
Supporting innovation and boosting
            competitiveness in Croatia

abstracts.cdata!:
Croatia is the birthplace of scientists
            like Nikola Tesla, whose discoveries made it possible for
            mankind to use electricity in everyday life. And of Rudjer
            Boskovic, whose 18th Century studies inspired the field of
            electromagnetism and whose work improved the performance of
            the royal society's telescopes and strengthened the
            dome of St. Peter's Basilica in Rome. Croatian
            scientists are still making important contributions,
            although most have yet to boost the country's economic
            development. Croatia's experience shows that innovation
            policies focused on supporting business R&D and enabling
            the commercialization of public research can achieve
            tangible results in a relatively short period of time. This
            is of particular importance in times of economic crisis when
            budgets are constrained and when economies need to unleash
            innovation and productivity as new drivers of economic
            growth,' says Paulo Correa, World Bank task manager for
            the Science and Technology Project.

Apoyar la innovación y estimular la
            competitividad en Croacia
